isPrime.TDD 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

    💛 isPrime.TDD

    Check given number is prime number with Test Driven Development in R language.

    📋 Prerequisites

    • R - 3.6.2
    • devtools - 2.2.1.9000
    • usethis - 1.5.1.9000
    • testthat - 2.3.1

    🚀 Note

    • I learned from this Video tutorial
    • For more information about testthat visit this reference

    🎨 Process

    🌷 Steps

    Make package with name (isPrime.TDD)

    Make isPrime.R file

    # isPrime.R

## EMPTY

    Make test

    • make test environment with usethis::use_test('isPrime') first
    • there’s no law with test creating, but I think basic result with working example could be good option
    # test-isPrime.R
test_that('use', {
 expect_equal(isPrime(2), TRUE) # 2 is prime number
 expect_equal(isPrime(4), FALSE) # 4 isnot prime number
})

    Run test (windows : ctrl+shift+t), and Fail it.

    Since there’s no function, we fix it until pass test with minimal efforts 1) make isPrime function 2) make isPrime(2) returns TRUE 3) make isPrimie(4) returns FALSE

    # isPrime.R
isPrime = function(x){
  if(x==2){return(TRUE)}
  for(i in 2:(x-1)){
    if(x%%i==0)return(FALSE)
  }
  return(TRUE)
}

    Pass on test

    i’m still confused in refactoring code part if you have advice, please let me know hwanistic@gmail.com

    Make another test with check format (or error)

    # test-isPrime.R
test_that('use',{
  expect_equal(isPrime(2), TRUE)
  expect_equal(isPrime(4), FALSE)
})

test_that('abuse', {
  expect_type(isPrime(2), 'logical')
  expect_error(isPrime('Hello World'),'x must be numeric value')
})

    Run test (windows : ctrl+shift+t), and Fail it.

    Fix it until pass test with minimal efforts 1) check isPrime function returns logical that is either TRUE or FALSE 2) make error message with x must be numeric value when x is not numeric value.

    # isPrime.R
isPrime = function(x){
  if(!is.numeric(x)){
    stop('x must be numeric value', call. = FALSE)
  }
  if(x==2){return(TRUE)}
  for(i in 2:(x-1)){
    if(x%%i==0)return(FALSE)
  }
  return(TRUE)
}

    Pass on test

    I think more improvement can not possible, so finish this and build package. (windows : ctrl + shift + b)
